application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

abstract.p: Punishment learning is learning of the causal relationship between responses and their adverse or undesirable consequences. Here we review our translational approach for understanding whether, when, and how individuals differ in what they learn during punishment and how these differences in learning may drive persistent poor or maladaptive decisions. We show that individual differences in punishment insensitivity can emerge from differences between individuals in what they learn about punishment (instrumental contingency knowledge), rather than differences in aversive valuation, reward valuation, general (impulsivity) or specific (habit) behavioral control. These differences in instrumental contingency knowledge are shared with and can be studied in other animals. Our approach has strong construct and predictive validity, providing a robust translational platform for studying how punishment learning and decision making may contribute to neuropsychiatric disorders.

div.p: Punishment learning is learning of the causal relationship between responses and their adverse or undesirable consequences (Bolles et al., 1980;Bolles et al., 1975;Mackintosh, 1983). This instrumental Response-Punisher knowledge may directly suppress behavior by causing withholding of a response, it may disincentivize behavior by undermining the motivational state that would otherwise generate that behavior (Mackintosh, 1983), or it may do both. Punishment learning is essential to healthy decision-making. It enables us to learn from our mistakes, thereby reducing behaviors that may cause us harm or be contrary to our better interests. Punishment learning is also a key tool for promoting behavior change in others. For example, parents use timeouts to reduce unwanted or problematic behaviors in their children, societies dissuade anti-social behaviors by using punishers ranging in severity from fines to incarceration. We share this use of punishment in maintaining social co-operation with chimpanzees (Riedl et al., 2012) and rhesus macaques (Hauser, 1992). There is some evidence that intra-species aggression may be used as a punisher by birds (Valera et al., 2003) and amphibians (Prosen et al., 2004). Crucially, differences between individuals in their sensitivity to punishment have been implicated in the etiology and maintenance of a range of neuropsychiatric disorders. These disorders include drug and behavioral addictions (Vanderschuren et al., 2017), conduct disorder (Briggs-Gowan et al., 2014;Dadds & Salmon, 2003), sociopathy and psychopathy (Blair et al., 2006;Gregory et al., 2015;Schmauk, 1970), depression (Elliott et al., 1996;Eshel & Roiser, 2010), and eating disorders (Monteleone et al., 2018). Given the central role of punishment learning in individual healthy decision-making and in maintaining co-operation and social cohesion, as well as evidence that disruptions in punishment learning contribute to some neuropsychiatric conditions, it is surprising that we know far less about the psychological and brain mechanisms for punishment learning than we do other closely related forms of learning such as instrumental reward learning and Pavlovian aversive (fear) learning. Moreover, much of the modern study of punishment does not adequately isolate punishment from these other learning processes. In recent years we have turned our attention to the study of punishment learning (Jean-Richard-Dit- Bressel et al., 2018;Jean-Richard-Dit-Bressel & McNally, 2014, 2015. Here we review our recent translational approach for understanding whether, when, and how individuals differ in what they learn during punishment and how these differences in learning may drive persistent poor or maladaptive decisions. The problematic history of the study of punishment learning Before reviewing our own recent work, it is worth considering the difficult history of the laboratory study of punishment learning. There are at least three reasons for our current relative lack of understanding of punishment learning compared to other forms of learning. First, the status of punishment learning as a learning process has been challenged. Based in part on work with Estes (Estes, 1944;Estes & Skinner, 1941), Skinner (Skinner, 1953(Skinner, , 2005 argued that because the behavioral effects of punishment were temporary and largely indistinguishable from those of fear, punishment learning could be reduced to Pavlovian fear learning. It was argued that animals, including humans, do not suppress a response because they know that it will cause them adverse consequences, but instead because stimuli linked to those consequences generate a competing emotional response of fear and other incompatible behaviors that displace the punished response. This challenge to the status of punishment as a distinct learning process spurred a highly productive period of research in the 1960s assessing whether, when, and how punishment may be isolated from fear (Boe & Church, 1968;Brush, 1971;Campbell & Church, 1969). This research successfully showed that punishment could be distinguished from fear and under what conditions. There are important procedural lessons from this research that are often lost on contemporary studies of punishment and fear; but, this body of work did little to advance a deeper theoretical understanding of punishment learning itself. Second, there has long been confusion between what is learned during punishment and how that learning changes behavior. Early thinking about what is learned during punishment was greatly influenced by cotemporaneous thinking about the nature of reinforcement. For example the Law of Effect asserted that punishment learning is opposite to reward learning (Thorndike, 1911), with reward stamping in and punishment stamping out behavior. The Law of Effect was aligned closely to the most popular view of reinforcement at the timepsychological hedonism (Spencer, 1872). Although Thorndike eventually rejected the Law of Effect as an adequate explanation for what is learned during punishment, stating that punishers "do not act on learning in general by weakening whatever connection they follow" (Thorndike, 1931) (p. 46), there is a clear intellectual link between the Law of Effect and the views of Hull (Hull, 1943), Azrin (Azrin & Holtz, 1966) Klopf (Klopf, 1972), Sutton and Barto (Sutton & Barto, 1981;Sutton & Barto, 1998) and modern reinforcement learning. Punishment is treated as opposite to reward learning at behavioral (reward increases rate of responding, punishment decreases rate of responding), computational (e.g., reward = +d, punishment =d) and neural (reward = ↑ dopamine release and activity/plasticity of drd1 neurons, punishment = ↓ dopamine release and ↑ activity/plasticity of drd2 neurons) levels. However, opposition between reward and punishment learning in terms of their effects on behavior does not require opposition in their underlying associative mechanisms. Indeed, there are far more parallels between these forms of instrumental learning (e.g., sensitivity to magnitude of reinforcement, delay of reinforcement, schedule of reinforcement, contingency of reinforcement, relative validity) than there are differences (Mackintosh, 1983). Instrumental punishment and instrumental reward share the same associative learning mechanisms, but they differ in how this learning affects behavior. Third, in his highly influential work 'Coercion and its Fallout', Sidman (Sidman, 1989) argued strongly against use of punishment as a tool for behavior change. Sidman revived and extended Skinner's criticisms of punishment. Sidman reasoned that even if punishment was effective in specifically suppressing unwanted behaviors, any such suppression was transient, was accompanied by the "toxic" side effect of conditioned punishment to environmental cues, and caused emergence of other unwanted behaviors (e.g., aggression). Although Sidman was later careful to distinguish between the use of punishment as a tool for behavioral control versus the utility of fundamental research on punishment learning itself (Holth, 2015), these criticisms of the utility and appropriateness of punishment undoubtedly slowed modern progress in understanding (for review see (Fontes & Shahan, 2021). Of course, there have been important exceptions. Punishment retained popularity in psychopharmacology as a behavioral screening tool for anxiolytics (Geller & Seifter, 1960) and 'addictive' behavior in laboratory animals (Deroche-Gamonet et al., 2004;Kasanetz et al., 2010;Kasanetz et al., 2013;Luscher et al., 2020;Pascoli et al., 2022;Pascoli et al., 2018;Vanderschuren et al., 2017), but this body of research was not intended to advance our understanding of punishment learning per se. Solomon argued for a theoretically driven focus on the nature of punishment learning (Solomon, 1964). Bolles used punishment to test formulation of a modern Response-Outcome perspective on instrumental learning (Bolles, 1972;Bolles et al., 1980;Bolles et al., 1975). Most recently, Bouton (Bouton & Broomer, 2023;Bouton et al., 2021;Bouton & Schepers, 2015) and Shahan (Fontes & Shahan, 2021 both re-directed theoretical attention on key aspects of punishment learning. However, these intellectual reprieves for the laboratory study of punishment learning have been few and far between. Meanwhile, the relevance of punishment to everyday learning and decision-making and the use of punishment to shape and control human behavior persists and the problems linked to individual differences in punishment responsivity remain largely unaddressed. In many respects, Solomon's conclusion that our "knowledge of the effects of punishment on instrumental and emotional behavior is...much too rudimentary to make an intelligent choice among conflicting ideas about it" (Solomon, 1964) (p. 252) remains applicable today. Individual differences in punishment sensitivity among non-human animals The ability to learn about the adverse consequences of our actions seems obviously adaptive because it allows us to avoid those consequences by subsequently withholding of those actions. Given this, an interesting feature of punishment learning is that it varies between individuals. There are easily detected differences among individual animals in punishment learning. Subjected to the same punishment contingencies, some rats or mice will suppress a response that causes punishment whereas others will not. These punishment insensitive individuals persist in behaviors that earn them punishment. This insensitivity seems counterintuitive: why would a rat or mouse persist in a behavior that earns them footshock? Not all individual differences are informative or interesting, but because many neuropsychiatric conditions are accompanied by deficits in punishment-related learning and decision-making, punishment insensitivity in rats and mice has become a leading model in behavioral neuroscience to study and understand decision-making deficits in these disorders (Augier et al., 2018;Domi et al., 2021;Marchant et al., 2018;Pascoli et al., 2022;Pascoli et al., 2018;Pascoli et al., 2015;Vanderschuren & Everitt, 2004;Vanderschuren et al., 2017). However, actual cause(s) for these inter-individual differences in punishment sensitivity in nonhuman animals are overlooked. Simply demonstrating differences between individuals in punishment suppression is not diagnostic of the mechanism of this difference. Until our own work, three main psychological mechanisms had been proposed. The historically most popular mechanism was based on Gray's reinforcement sensitivity theory, which argued that individual differences in punishment learning are due to general temperamental differences in aversive valuation or aversion sensitivity (Corr, 2004;Corr et al., 1995;Gray, 1982Gray, , 1987. Increased sensitivity to the aversiveness of punishers should suppress behaviors that produced punishers more than those less bothered by these punishers. A second possibility is that animals may persist in their punished behavior (i.e. show punishment insensitivity) because they overvalue the reward associated with that action. For such individuals, the reward is thought to dominate the cost-benefit equation, such that steep costs (i.e. punishment) fail to bias choices. That is, behavior is more strongly determined by the value of rewards they earn over the punishments they incur (O'Brien & Frick, 1996;Robinson & Berridge, 1993). Another popular account for the persistence of punished behavior is that not all individuals have the necessary control over their own behavior to avoid punishment. Impulsive individuals or those with compulsions may lack general or specific control, respectively, over behaviors with negative consequences, such that even if the negative consequences are acknowledged, or the "reward" is no longer desired, the behavior persists, e.g. out of habit (Everitt et al., 2008). Mechanistic behavioral assessment of differences in punishment sensitivity in non-human animals is not straightforward. Perhaps the most popular way of distinguishing between these different mechanisms is to directly assess nocifensive responses such as flinching or jumping to the aversive event directly (Pascoli et al., 2018;Pascoli et al., 2015). However, the magnitude of the unconditioned response to a stimulus is not especially informative about what is learned about that stimulus (Rescorla, 1988). Our approach (Jean-Richard-Dit-Bressel et al., 2019) ( Figure 1A) was to use a task in rats that isolates and dissociates different forms of learning about events to reveal what relationships, if any, exist between them. This strategy allows identification of any shared variance between different learning processes and the diagnosis of any potential common origin. Based on the work of Killcross (Killcross et al., 1997), we trained rats to respond on two levers for food reward. In the punishment phase, both levers were always available and earned reward. We introduced a conditioned punishment contingency on one lever but not the other. So, R1 à CS1+ and R2 à CS-, (where + = footshock and -= no footshock). In this task, punishment learning can be measured via rates of R1 (punished) responding outside CS presentations relative to R2 (unpunished) or pre-punishment rates. Pavlovian fear learning can be measure via rates of R1 and R2 during presentations of the CS+ (fear) versus CS-(safe). Finally, reward learning can be measured via rates of R2 responding as well as responding prior to punishment. There are several features of this task that deserve comment. First, this task permits assessment of these different forms of learning (instrumental punishment, instrumental reward, Pavlovian fear) in the same individuals. Second, these different forms of learning are assessed at the same time. Finally, the same behavioral measure is used to quantify these different forms of learning. So, this task is unique in permitting fair comparison of these different forms of learning and in allowing analysis techniques to assess and quantify the relationships between them. For example, if individual differences in punishment sensitivity are due to individual differences in aversive valuation, then this would be reflected in other forms of learning about the aversive event in the same individuals. So, individuals impaired in punishment learning should also be impaired in Pavlovian fear conditioning. If individual differences in punishment sensitivity are due to differences in reward dominance, then individual differences in punishment learning should be related to differences in instrumental reward seeking. If individual differences in punishment insensitivity are attributable to punishment-specific deficits, then no relationship between the three forms of learning should be apparent. Using this task, we replicated past findings of robust individual differences in punishment learning ( Figure 1B). Some rats showed robust punishment suppression (R1 < R2) whereas some rats did not. However, all rats showed robust Pavlovian fear to the CS+ and not the CS-. These differences in Pavlovian versus instrumental suppression are important, but they are not themselves diagnostic of the extent of shared variance between the two. So, we used a variety of data analytic strategies (k-means clustering, multidimensional scaling, principal components analysis, and factor analysis) to understand the relationship between individual differences in instrumental reward learning, instrumental punishment learning, and Pavlovian fear learning. There were several important findings, but the most relevant here was that punishment, fear and reward were remarkably independent from each other. They shared little variance. Punishment insensitivity is a specific phenotype unrelated to differences in instrumental reward learning or Pavlovian fear learning. Additionally, punishment insensitive animals suppressed both R1 and R2 relative to pre-punishment, indicating an intact capacity to withhold behavior. This contradicts a behavioral control (i.e. habit) account for differences observed. Taken together, our work in rats indicated a separate mechanism driving individual differences in punishment. This mechanism emerges directly from the fact that punishment learning involves encoding the instrumental contingency between behavior and its adverse consequences (i.e. the response à outcome contingency). Punishment insensitive and sensitive individuals encode the punisher as equally aversive but differ in their ability to detect or encode the contingency between their behavior and the punisher. Translating from non-human to human punishment learning Our findings from animal laboratory studies raised the question: does the same mechanism operate in humans to drive individual differences in punishment learning? The most popular measure of punishment sensitivity in humans (>9,000 citations, Google Scholar) has been self-reporting via the Behavioral Inhibition/Behavioral Activation Scales (Carver & White, 1994). Based on Gray's model of reinforcement sensitivity theory, this questionnaire measure requires participants to rate, using a 4-point Likert scale, items such as "I worry about making mistakes", "Criticism or scolding hurts me quite a bit", and "I have very few fears compared to my friends" (p. 323). It was validated by requiring participants to complete a series of problems which had no correct solution. Participants were provided with manipulated feedback indicating their performance was suboptimal and that they would thus be exposed to a cold pressor stressor that they knew from experience to be aversive. The key outcome variable was participants self-reported level of "nervousness" in anticipation of experiencing the cold pressor. BIS scores modestly but significantly predicted changes in nervousness produced by stressor expectation, explaining 9% of the changes in variance in nervousness scores. There are robust differences between individuals in their BIS scores that depend on a myriad of factors and there is a large literature on what, and how well, the BIS actually measures behavioral inhibition and aversive valuation (Poythress et al., 2008). For present purposes the important point is that the BIS was intentionally designed to assess aversive valuation. Close in popularity (>8,000 citations, Google Scholar) is the Iowa Gambling Task (Bechara, 1994). Here, participants are presented with starting funds and told that the goal is to maximize profit on these funds. They are required to select a card from one of four different decks. The four decks are designed with different reward and punishment contingencies. Two decks, A and B, always yield $100 reward per choice whereas the two other decks always yield $50 reward per choice. However, Decks A and B have a punishment contingency resulting in $1,250 in losses across 10 selections (netting -$250 over 10 cards). Decks C and D also have a punishment contingency but only incur $250 in losses across 10 selections (netting +$250 over 10 cards). So, in the long run, participants lose more money than they earn when choosing from Decks A and B, and earn more money than they lose when choosing Decks C and D. A review of the Iowa Gambling Task is beyond the scope of this paper and the interested reader is referred to other reviews (Brevers et al., 2013;Toplak et al., 2010), but is worth noting that this task has been back-translated to assess risky decision-making in laboratory animals (de Visser et al., 2011;Orsini & Setlow, 2017;Orsini et al., 2015;St Onge et al., 2012;St Onge & Floresco, 2010). Despite their widespread popularity, neither the BIS nor the Iowa Gambling Task are well suited to identifying the mechanisms that may cause humans to differ in punishment avoidance. The BIS is a questionnaire-based instrument that does not discriminate between aversive valuation based on Pavlovian (fear) and instrumental (punishment) knowledge. The Iowa Gambling Task potently identifies maladaptive decision-making tendencies but fails to provide insight into the psychological mechanisms of these tendencies because it confounds differences in rewarding and punishing contingencies across decks. Advantageous versus disadvantageous decks differ in their punisher magnitude (low versus high), but also their reward magnitude (low versus high) and outcome frequency (reliable reward versus unreliable punishment). This obscures relative contributions of punishment-versus reward-related learning, motivation, ability to detect weak contingencies, and sensitivity to uncertainty. Leveraging the extra capacity for insight from the conditioned punishment design, we developed a digital 'Planets and Pirates' variant of the rodent conditioned punishment task for use in humans ( Figure 1C) (Jean-Richard-Dit- . In this task, participants play a game in which their goal is accumulate points. They can accumulate points by clicking on two different planets (R1 and R2). Then, in the conditioned punishment phase, responses on Planet (R1) cause a ship (CS1) to appear and this ship steals a percentage of the participants accumulated points. Responses on the other planet, Planet (R2), also cause a ship (CS2) to appear but this ship is a safe ship that does not steal any points. The behavioral dependent variable is rate of clicking. The various probabilities of these events as well as the magnitude of punishment are under experimenter control. Crucially, although the surface features are different to the laboratory animal task, Planets and Pirates has the same associative structure as the rodent conditioned punishment task described previously: R1 à CS1+, R2à CS2-. Moreover, like the rodent task, the same behavioral measure (response rates) is used to quantify the different forms of learning. Using this task, we could identify punishment sensitive and insensitive humans in similar ways to how we identified punishment sensitive and insensitive rats (Jean-Richard-Dit- . Punishment sensitive individuals selectively suppressed R1, the response causing punishment, and re-allocated their behavior to R2, the unpunished response whereas punishment insensitive individuals did not ( Figure 1C). Like our work in rats, these differences in human punishment suppression were not attributable to differences in Pavlovian learning, showing that differences in punishment learning can be divorced from differences in Pavlovian fear learning in humans. The Planets and Pirates task also took advantage of the unique ability of human participants to verbalize their beliefs and subjective valuation of reward and punishment. That is, we could directly assess declared subjective valuations of reward and punishment to show that differences in punishment sensitivity were not due to differences in these subjective valuations: all participants expressed liking rewards and disliking punishment. We could also directly assess contingency knowledge by asking participants to rate their likelihood estimates of the specific events (e.g., R1à CS1, R1àCS2, R2àCS1, R2 à CS2, R1 à point loss, R2 à point loss etc). Explicit awareness of task contingencies is essential to human associative learning (Lovibond et al., 2011;Weidemann et al., 2013;Weidemann et al., 2016). We showed that all participants developed a causal mental model of the task and that these models were generally coherent. However, whereas punishment sensitive individuals had learned a correct causal model (i.e. R1 à CS1+, R2à CS2-), punishment insensitive participants had not. Instead, punishment insensitive participants had learned incorrect models (e.g., R1 à CS1+, R2àCS1+). So, punishment insensitivity in humans, as in other animals, can be driven by a lack of learning the correct instrumental contingency between behaviour and punishment. It is worth noting that these differences in punishment learning were not accounted for by differences in self-reported impulsivity and BIS (Jean-Richard-Dit- . Although a lack of awareness about the consequences of one's actions can cause insensitivity to punishment, lacking awareness is not inherently problematic. In fact, lack of correct awareness of punishment contingencies may be quite common because punishment contingencies vary in their visibility to the individual. Adverse consequences from our actions vary in the their severity, are often delayed relative to, and imperfectly correlated with, the actions that earn them (Meindl & Casey, 2012). Moreover, humans learn in different ways (e.g., personal experience, observation, instruction) and we readily integrate knowledge and evidence from different modalities to improve our understanding. We do not need to experience a traffic accident to reduce our driving speed in dangerous conditions or to experience poisoning to avoid consumption of a known toxin. So, failing to correctly learn about punishment from one source (e.g., experience) does not mean that behavior is fundamentally resistant to change or that this failure of learning is theoretically interesting or practically important. Indeed, any account of human punishment sensitivity that relies only on experiencing punishment is out of touch with many of the key factors that govern human decision-making and behavior. In follow up experiments we again took advantage of the unique language abilities of human participants to further understand the causes of punishment sensitivity (Jean-Richard-Dit- . Participants played the Planets and Pirates task. However, now after experiencing three blocks of punishment training, we provided explicit information to all participants about the punishment contingencies via a contingency reveal. We provided written instruction on the punishment contingencies (R1 à CS1+, R2à CS2-) and participants were required to pass a knowledge test indicating correct understanding of these contingencies prior to a final block of training ( Figure 1D). Prior to the contingency reveal, when participants were required to learn punishment from their experience alone, we replicated our previous finding that some people could correctly learn these contingencies and show punishment sensitivity whereas other people incorrectly learned these contingencies and were punishment insensitive. Crucially, information about the punishment contingencies was a potent means of addressing this lack of correct awareness, rescuing most of the insensitive participants and rendering them punishment sensitive. We labelled these individuals 'unaware' because their punishment insensitivity was corrected via provision of contingency information. However, for some participants, provision of correct contingency information did not change their behaviour. Even when punishment was severe, these individuals persisted in earning punishment they did not like. We labelled these individuals 'compulsive' because they did not learn punishment correctly from experience and they did not change their behavior when provided with correct contingency information. Importantly, the impact of information depended on the participants prior experiences with punishment (i.e. punishment contingencies). When punishment had been rare, participants were less likely to benefit from explicit instruction and less likely to change behavior (i.e. they were more likely to be compulsive). Together, our findings across rodents and humans show that there is a cognitive pathway to punishment insensitivity (McNally et al., 2023). This pathway emerges from differences between individuals in what they learn about punishment (instrumental contingency knowledge). These differences are shared with and can be studied in other animals. These differences are not necessarily problematic. However, they can become problematic. At least one condition when this is likely is when punishment is rare. Rare punishment acts as a 'trap', inoculating maladaptive behavioral preferences against cognitive (i.e., informational) and behavioral (i.e., experiential) updating. One important direction of our current work is characterizing the cognitive and computational underpinnings of these punishment traps (Jarvis & Chong, 2023; as well as determining interventions that can rescue individuals from these traps. Lessons in translation Our cross-species approach to study punishment learning has enjoyed some success. Our work shows that fundamental research into underpinnings for individual differences in punishment avoidance can be robustly translated across species. We think there are several features of our approach that have contributed to this success.

1. This cross-species paradigm goes beyond simple face validity, a common but insufficient criterion for translational research, by empirically assessing fundamental underpinnings of behavior to achieve construct and predictive validity. 2. The behavioral task that underpins our work is theoretically-driven and well-controlled.

It permits isolation and assessment of different forms of learning -instrumental punishment, instrumental reward, Pavlovian fear -in the same individuals at the same time to triangulate what might be determining an individual's behavior. 3. The same behavioral measure is used to quantify different forms of learning within the individual. This common assessment technique overcomes difficult problems in comparing different forms of learning using different measures. 4. A similar behavioral measure is used between species: lever pressing in laboratory animals and screen clicking in humans. 5. We have taken advantage of the unique ability of humans to express their understanding in language by directly assessing the causal models that they mentally form from their experiences. Our work shows that humans develop and use specific Response-Outcome models during punishment learning. Our work also shows that there is close alignment between the content of these models and their behavior. So, people engage in behaviors that have adverse consequences because they have formed incorrect causal models of their environment. 6. We have taken advantage of the human ability to comprehend abstract ideas through language to affect human participants' understanding and expectations. This capacity to communicate abstract ideas through language is fundamental to cost-effectively solving the problems created by individual differences in punishment learning. For example, education and media campaigns are widely and successfully used to reduce problematic behavior at the community level. At the individual level, cognitive restructuring is the central basis of effective psychological therapeutic intervention.

The lack of such cognitive capacities in laboratory animals does not reduce the significance or importance of laboratory research (as shown here), but the presence of this capacity in humans should not be ignored. Ignoring this unique capacity reduces the relevance of behavioral neuroscience research and its potential to impact key stakeholders including policy-makers, clinicians, and individual sufferers of neuropsychiatric disorders (de Wit et al., 2018). 7. Finally, there are more 'translational pathways' than laboratory animals à patient group. The study of learning processes in otherwise healthy human participants is a crucial waypoint in the translational research process. It can identify cognitive processes that are difficult to interrogate in non-human animals and that may be directly relevant to neuropsychiatric disorders. Figure 1. A. Design of conditioned punishment task based on Killcross et al. (1997). + indicates reward (food pellet for rodents, points gain for humans) + indicates punishment (footshock for rodents, points loss for humans). B. Punishment sensitive rats show selective suppression of responding on the punished lever (R1) whereas punishment insensitive rats do not. C. The Planets and Pirates task where participants click on Planet 1 (R1) and Planet R2 (R2) to gain points and are selectively punished for responses on Planet 1 via presentations of a Pirate Ship (CS+) that steals their points. Punishment sensitive people show selective suppression of responding on the punished planet (R1) whereas punishment insensitive people do not. D. Explicit information in the form of correct contingency information after the third training block reveals that punishment insensitivity in people can be due to lack of correct awareness of the punishment contingencies (unaware) or it can be due to lack of correct awareness of the punishment contingencies and failure to change behavior when provided with correct contingency information (Compulsive).

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: The work described here was supported by grants from the Australian Research Council (PJRDB: DP220102317; GPM: DP220100040 and DP200102576). GPM is supported by an NHMRC Synergy grant (GNT2011633). We thank the members of our laboratory and Nathan Marchant for discussions of this work.
